Award.AwardTitle: NSF MRI: Acquisition of a 755 Superconducting Rock Magnetometer System to Enhance the Paleomagnetic and Rock Magnetic Laboratory at New Mexico Highlands University
Award.AbstractNarration:
1623807
Petronis

This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant supports acquisition of a superconducting rock magnetometer (SRM) equipped with an in-line alternating field demagnetizer and automated sample handling system for the Department of Natural Sciences at New Mexico Highlands University (NMHU). The SRM will complement extant paleo and rock magnetic analytical equipment at NMHU and will serve as a state and regional facility for investigation for the magnetic properties of natural materials. The facility will support multiple national and international collaborative science projects. This support is congruent with NSFs mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing the national health, prosperity and welfare given the importance of training underrepresented students in methods of analysis and scientific research. NMHU is a primarily undergraduate and Hispanic Serving Institution and the investigator has a strong track record of engaging undergraduates student in laboratory and field research. Many of the students at NMHU are first-generation college students.

The new SRM will support a wide range of research and research training applications requiring the ability to determine the magnetic remanence of often weakly magnetized materials , including studies of crustal deformation processes based on paleomagnetic and rock magnetic fabric analysis, studies of past climate conditions based on paleomagnetic proxies, paleomagnetic investigations of shallow crustal magma emplacement processes, investigation of the timing of deposition of important continental aquifers, and the timing and extent of Neoproterozoic cap carbonates indicative of past global glaciation events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Funds were requested for the acquisition of a 2G Enterprise 760-4K Superconducting Rock Magnetometer System (760-4K) to complement the recently established (2009) paleomagnetic-rock magnetic laboratory (PRML) at New Mexico Highlands University (NMHU). Many future and funded research projects are to benefit from the acquisition of the 760-4K as it will expand the range of materials that can be analyzed, provide the means for rapid processing of a variety of samples, dramatically open new doors into material science research, increase opportunities for research partnerships regionally, nationally, and internationally, and advance student learning opportunities at the undergraduate and graduate levels.

 

Broader Impact: The PRML is the only facility available for paleomagnetic teaching and research in New Mexico, eastern Arizona, and southern Colorado. The new instrument will dramatically raise the productivity of research conducted, support a wide range of collaborative investigations, and open research doors currently not available at the lab. The future and funded activities will also advance the mission of NSF by training and fostering research for minority and underrepresented students and serve NMHU's mission to provide modern research and teaching facilities. Student skill sets to be improved consist of paleomagnetic research and basic science applications that will build their experience levels and confidence to succeed and level the playing field to competitively compete. Graduate students awarded a Master's degree from the PRML have either gone on to purse advanced degrees or obtained employment at state and federal agencies. These include PhD programs, Los Alamos National Lab & NASA, Environmental Consulting firms, and the Office of the State Engineer. Demographics for this student cohort include African Americans, Hispanics, and Native American with the majority of these students female. The success stories of the PRML's former students attest to the cutting edge and transformative research being conducted.

 

Intellectual Merit: The acquisition will support a wide range of national and international collaborative investigations that will enhance the ability to conduct fundamental and transformative research in a cost-effective and productive manner including studies, but not limited to: understanding the principles of materials design, materials synthesis, and materials applications in areas of electronic, optical and magnetic properties and theoretical research quantifying the transport behavior of nanoparticles through porous materials (both new research directions). Other new and ongoing activities include paleomagnetic and structural analysis of crustal deformation, rock magnetic properties of Earth materials, paleoclimate research, growth and deformation of volcanic constructs, shallow crustal magmatic emplacement, the interaction of glacier ice and sub-glacier deformation, and Neoproterozoic plate configurations.  The new 760-4K will make available an in-house service and teaching laboratory and train the next generation of scientists in the use of specialized geophysical equipment as well as advancing more national and international collaborations further building the reputation of northern New Mexico's premier Hispanic serving institution, recruiting students into STEM, and providing an all inclusive facility to conduct transformative and forward-looking research.
